elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) View of the coordination environment of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 0.5−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> and (ii) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. (b) View of the Zn–Zn linear chain connected by the bridging nic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the wavy 2D layer structure constructed from Zn–Zn linear chains and atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands. (d) Topological view of the 2D 4-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> networks. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn2+ in complex 1 at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 0.5-x, 0.5+y, z and (ii) x, 0.5-y, 0.5+z. (b) View of the Zn-Zn linear chain connected by the bridging nic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the wavy 2D layer structure constructed from Zn-Zn linear chains and atz- ligands. (d) Topological view of the 2D 4-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of 44⋅62 networks. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) View of the coordination environment of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> and (ii) −0.5+<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −0.5+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. (b) View of the Zn–Zn zigzag chain connected by the bridging isonic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the single 3D network constructed from the Zn–Zn zigzag chains and the atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands. (d) Topological view showing the individual diamondoid network for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> along approximate [001] direction with the Schläfli symbol of 66 network. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls. (e) View of the 2-fold-interpenetrated 3D topological network for 2 constructed from two identical diamondoid net along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis. Zn nodes are represented by cyan and purple balls. (f) View of the 2-fold interpenetration 3D network for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> including free Hisonic in the cavities. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn2+ in complex 2 at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, -y, 0.5+z and (ii) -0.5+x, 0.5-y, -0.5+z. (b) View of the Zn-Zn zigzag chain connected by the bridging isonic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the single 3D network constructed from the Zn-Zn zigzag chains and the atz- ligands. (d) Topological view showing the individual diamondoid network for complex 2 along approximate [001] direction with the Schläfli symbol of 66 network. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls. (e) View of the 2-fold-interpenetrated 3D topological network for 2 constructed from two identical diamondoid net along c-axis. Zn nodes are represented by cyan and purple balls. (f) View of the 2-fold interpenetration 3D network for complex 2 including free Hisonic in the cavities. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) View of the coordination environment of Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> at 50% probability level with labeling schedule. Hydrogen atoms are omitted. Symmetry codes: (i) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (ii) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (iii) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (iv) 1+<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> and (vi) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.51−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. (b) Single 2D framework constructed from the double M–O–M chains and the pyridyl ring spacers. (c) View of the 3D framework in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> formed by the pillared atz ligand along the bc plane. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: blue=N; gray=C; red=O; cyan=Cd. (d) View of the 3D (4,6)-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·8) network for complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Cd and isonic nodes are represented by blue and cyan balls, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) View of the coordination environment of Cd2+ in complex 3 at 50% probability level with labeling schedule. Hydrogen atoms are omitted. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 0.5-y, 1-z; (ii) -x, -y, 1-z; (iii) -x, 0.5+y, z; (iv) 1+x, y, z and (vi) x, y, 0.51-z. (b) Single 2D framework constructed from the double M-O-M chains and the pyridyl ring spacers. (c) View of the 3D framework in 3 formed by the pillared atz ligand along the bc plane. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: blue=N; gray=C; red=O; cyan=Cd. (d) View of the 3D (4,6)-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of (44⋅62)(44⋅610⋅8) network for complex 3. Cd and isonic nodes are represented by blue and cyan balls, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Three new metal–organic frameworks, [Zn(atz)(nic)]<ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>Hisonic(2) and [Cd(atz)(isonic)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(3) (Hnic=nicotinic acid, Hisonic=isonicotinic acid), have been firstly synthesized by employing mixed-ligand of pyridinecarboxylate with the <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate(atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>), and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, TGA and single crystal X-ray diffraction. The results revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a two-dimensional (2D) “sql” topological network constructed from the linear chain subunit of Zn(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand. A remarkable feature of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a 2-fold interpenetrated diamondoid network with free Hisonic molecules locating in the channels formed by the zigzag chain subunits of Zn(isonic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a 3D non-interpenetrated pillared framework constructed from the double chain subunits of Cd–COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>–Cd. It possesses a rarely observed (4,6)-connected “<ce:italic>fsc</ce:italic>” topology. The thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of the complexes were investigated. All of these complexes exhibited intense fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three new metal-organic frameworks, [Zn(atz)(nic)] n (1), [Zn(atz)(isonic)] n ⋅nHisonic(2) and [Cd(atz)(isonic)] n (3) (Hnic=nicotinic acid, Hisonic=isonicotinic acid), have been firstly synthesized by employing mixed-ligand of pyridinecarboxylate with the in situ generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate(atz-), and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, TGA and single crystal X-ray diffraction. The results revealed that 1 presents a two-dimensional (2D) "sql" topological network constructed from the linear chain subunit of Zn(nic)2 and atz- ligand. A remarkable feature of 2 is a 2-fold interpenetrated diamondoid network with free Hisonic molecules locating in the channels formed by the zigzag chain subunits of Zn(isonic)2. Complex 3 is a 3D non-interpenetrated pillared framework constructed from the double chain subunits of Cd-COO--Cd. It possesses a rarely observed (4,6)-connected "fsc" topology. The thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of the complexes were investigated. All of these complexes exhibited intense fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In recent years a new research field has been developed in the tetrazole chemistry, coordination complexes containing a tetrazole group have been the subject of an intense research effort due to their variety of intriguing architectures and their potential applications in advanced materials . Numerous metal–organic coordination complexes constructed from tetrazole-based ligand have been reported, such as the low-dimensional structures of transition metal complexes of tetrazolate and derivatives (1-<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>-tetrazoles), <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>=alkyl , phenyl , chloroethyl  and methoxyethyl  etc. However, the unfunctionalized substituents show no coordination ability and thus disfavor the formation of highly extended structures. In order to construct high-dimensional metal–tetrazolate materials, a good synthetic strategy is to utilize different functional groups to functionalized-substitute tetrazolate. Thanks to the pioneering work of Demko & Sharpless, tetrazole-based ligands can be obtained by an environmentally friendly process . Many functionalized-substituted tetrazoles and derivatives have been produced such as pyridyl-tetrazole (PTZ), pyrimidyl-tetrazole (PMTZ) carboxylate-tetrazole, bistetrazole (BTZ), and aminotetrazole (ATZ) etc., and several extended high-dimensional metal–organic coordination complexes  have been synthesized and structurally characterized. In recent research, chemists have concentrated on the construction of mixed-ligand MOFs based on triazolate-system and carboxylate species and got some unique 3D architectures or 2-fold interpenetrating layered networks . These results reveal that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is reliable to achieve unusual MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years a new research field has been developed in the tetrazole chemistry, coordination complexes containing a tetrazole group have been the subject of an intense research effort due to their variety of intriguing architectures and their potential applications in advanced materials . Numerous metal-organic coordination complexes constructed from tetrazole-based ligand have been reported, such as the low-dimensional structures of transition metal complexes of tetrazolate and derivatives (1-R-tetrazoles), R=alkyl , phenyl , chloroethyl  and methoxyethyl  etc. However, the unfunctionalized substituents show no coordination ability and thus disfavor the formation of highly extended structures. In order to construct high-dimensional metal-tetrazolate materials, a good synthetic strategy is to utilize different functional groups to functionalized-substitute tetrazolate. Thanks to the pioneering work of Demko & Sharpless, tetrazole-based ligands can be obtained by an environmentally friendly process . Many functionalized-substituted tetrazoles and derivatives have been produced such as pyridyl-tetrazole (PTZ), pyrimidyl-tetrazole (PMTZ) carboxylate-tetrazole, bistetrazole (BTZ), and aminotetrazole (ATZ) etc., and several extended high-dimensional metal-organic coordination complexes  have been synthesized and structurally characterized. In recent research, chemists have concentrated on the construction of mixed-ligand MOFs based on triazolate-system and carboxylate species and got some unique 3D architectures or 2-fold interpenetrating layered networks . These results reveal that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is reliable to achieve unusual MOFs.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Nicotinic acid and isonicotinic acid, as good sources of carboxylate ligand, have been wildly applied to construct MOFs. We apply nicotinic or isonicotinic acid in the tetrazole-based system as a second ligand based on the following considerations: (i) nicotinic acid and isonicotinic acid are positional isomers with both N and O donor atoms. They have been proven to be able to form novel structures with different metal ions ; (ii) nicotinic acid and isonicotinic acid, the difference in the coordination orientation of the two binding sites, py and carboxylate groups, straight for isonic, and bent for nic, would affect the crystal structure and properties of a complex. While compared with those reported metal–tetrazolate cases, mixed-ligand coordination complexes with tetrazole and carboxylic acid ligands are rarely presented up to now. Herein we report three new complexes [Zn(atz)(nic)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(1), [Zn(atz)(isonic)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>Hisonic (2) and [Cd(atz)(isonic)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(3) (Hnic=nicotinic acid, Hisonic=isonicotinic acid), which were constructed from the reaction of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) with mixed-ligand of pyridinecarboxylate and the <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate. The thermal stabilities and photoluminescence properties of the complexes have also been studied.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Nicotinic acid and isonicotinic acid, as good sources of carboxylate ligand, have been wildly applied to construct MOFs. We apply nicotinic or isonicotinic acid in the tetrazole-based system as a second ligand based on the following considerations: (i) nicotinic acid and isonicotinic acid are positional isomers with both N and O donor atoms. They have been proven to be able to form novel structures with different metal ions ; (ii) nicotinic acid and isonicotinic acid, the difference in the coordination orientation of the two binding sites, py and carboxylate groups, straight for isonic, and bent for nic, would affect the crystal structure and properties of a complex. While compared with those reported metal-tetrazolate cases, mixed-ligand coordination complexes with tetrazole and carboxylic acid ligands are rarely presented up to now. Herein we report three new complexes [Zn(atz)(nic)] n (1), [Zn(atz)(isonic)] n ⋅nHisonic (2) and [Cd(atz)(isonic)] n (3) (Hnic=nicotinic acid, Hisonic=isonicotinic acid), which were constructed from the reaction of Zn2+ (or Cd2+) with mixed-ligand of pyridinecarboxylate and the in situ generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate. The thermal stabilities and photoluminescence properties of the complexes have also been studied.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Reagents and physical measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on a Perkin-Elmer FT-IR spectrum 2000 spectrometers using KBr pellets. Elemental analyses were determined with a Perkin-Elmer model 240C instrument. The fluorescent spectra were recorded on an Edinburgh Instrument FL/FS-920 fluorescent spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Delta Series TGA7 instrument in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere with heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>min from 40 to 900<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Reagents and physical measurements

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Infrared spectra were recorded in the range 4000-400cm-1 on a Perkin-Elmer FT-IR spectrum 2000 spectrometers using KBr pellets. Elemental analyses were determined with a Perkin-Elmer model 240C instrument. The fluorescent spectra were recorded on an Edinburgh Instrument FL/FS-920 fluorescent spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a Delta Series TGA7 instrument in N2 atmosphere with heating rate of 10°Cmin from 40 to 900°C.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of   [  Zn  (  atz  ) (  nic  )   ]   n   (  1  )   

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2975g, 1.0mmol), NaN3 (0.0325g, 0.5mmol), DCDA (DCDA=dicyandiamide, 0.042g, 0.5mmol), Hnic (0.122g, 1.0mmol) ethanol (2ml) and water (8ml) was stirred for 30min in air ( ), then sealed in a 23ml Teflon autoclave and heated at 130°C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°C/h, colorless lamellar crystals were obtained in ca. 38% yield based on Zn. Anal. found: C, 31.03%; H, 2.21%; N, 30.91%. Calcd for Zn2C14H12N12O4 (MW=543.10): C, 30.96%; H, 2.23%; N, 30.95%.

<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallographic determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Suitable single crystals of three complexes were mounted on glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation(<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å). Crystal structures were solved by the direct method and different Fourier syntheses. All calculations were performed using the SHELX-97 program . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the free Hisonic ligand is disordered in two reversed directions. Crystal data and details of the data collection and the structure refinement are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and bond angles of the complexes are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic determination

Suitable single crystals of three complexes were mounted on glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation(λ=0.71073Å). Crystal structures were solved by the direct method and different Fourier syntheses. All calculations were performed using the SHELX-97 program . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. In complex 2, the free Hisonic ligand is disordered in two reversed directions. Crystal data and details of the data collection and the structure refinement are given in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of the complexes are listed in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

Hydrothermal reaction (130°C) of NaN3, dicyandiamide, Hisonic, ethanol and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (for 2), or Cd(NO3)2⋅2H2O (for 3) in water in different molar ratios yielded [Zn(atz)(isonic)] n ⋅n(Hisonic)(2), [Cd(atz)(isonic)] n (3). While the corresponding reactions of dicyandiamide with NaN3 and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (or Cd(NO3)2⋅2H2O) in the replacement of Hisonic with Hnic gave [Zn(atz)(nic)] n (1), but failed in preparing the complex of Cd with nic and atz, only led to white powder, although the reaction temperature was changed from 100 to 180°C.

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of complex    1    

The different coordination modes of the nic, isonic and atz ligands in the three complexes are listed in  a-d.

Single crystal X-ray analysis shows that complex 1 is a 2D square lattice structure. There is one four-coordinated Zn(II) atom, one nic ligand, and one atz ligand in the asymmetric unit, of which the Zn(II) atom, nic and atz ligands are all sited in the general position ( a). The Zn(II) ion is coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from two bridging μ 2-atz- ligands (N5 and N2(i)) and one nic ligand (N6) (a and d), one monodentate carboxylate group oxygen atom (O1(ii)) from the other inic groups, to form a slightly distorted ZnN3O tetrahedron with the cis-bond angles ranging from 102.0(2)-112.7(2)°. The bond length of Zn-N range from 1.995(5)-2.048(5)Å, Zn1-O1(ii) bond length is 1.999(4)Å. All the Zn-N and Zn-O bond lengths are comparable to those of the Zn(II)-tetrazole and the Zn(II)-nicotinate compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In this structure, the ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O tetrahedra are bridged into a linear chain by <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-nic<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (N,O) ligand along the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane (b), then the linear chains are linked into wavy 2D layer by the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis (c) direction and formed a “sql” topology with the Schläfli symbol  of 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and the vertex symbol or long symbol , of 4·4·4·4·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (d). The wavy 2D layers are stabilized by the weak intralayer N–H…O hydrogen bonding interactions (N1–H3…O2(♯3), 2.915<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å N1–H6…O2(♯2), 2.928<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å), via the amino groups donating H atoms to the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (c). The layers further pack along [100] direction into a 3D supramolecular structure via weak <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> stacking interaction between the neighboring pyridyl ring of two nic ligands (Figure S1, Supporting information). The two adjacent pyridyl rings are paralleling to each other with a distance of 3.906(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å and slight offset (the centroid-to-centroid distance of the two pyridyl rings is 3.954(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å. Compared with the similar structure reported by Xiong's group , the size of square grid Zn–Zn–Zn–Zn increased effectively via the nic ligand replacement of the OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>group. The distances between Zn–Zn are 7.837 and 6.143<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> much larger than that distances of 3.369 and 6.105<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å in the reported case. Another most different feature of the two comparable complexes is, interestingly, all of the atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> grow almost in one direction (along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis direction) due to the N–H…O hydrogen bonding interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this structure, the ZnN3O tetrahedra are bridged into a linear chain by μ 2-nic- (N,O) ligand along the bc plane (b), then the linear chains are linked into wavy 2D layer by the μ 2-atz- ligand along the b-axis (c) direction and formed a "sql" topology with the Schläfli symbol  of 44⋅62 and the vertex symbol or long symbol , of 4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅62⋅62 (d). The wavy 2D layers are stabilized by the weak intralayer N-H…O hydrogen bonding interactions (N1-H3…O2(♯3), 2.915Å N1-H6…O2(♯2), 2.928Å), via the amino groups donating H atoms to the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (c). The layers further pack along [100] direction into a 3D supramolecular structure via weak π…π stacking interaction between the neighboring pyridyl ring of two nic ligands (Figure S1, Supporting information). The two adjacent pyridyl rings are paralleling to each other with a distance of 3.906(3)Å and slight offset (the centroid-to-centroid distance of the two pyridyl rings is 3.954(1)Å. Compared with the similar structure reported by Xiong's group , the size of square grid Zn-Zn-Zn-Zn increased effectively via the nic ligand replacement of the OH-group. The distances between Zn-Zn are 7.837 and 6.143Å in complex 1 much larger than that distances of 3.369 and 6.105Å in the reported case. Another most different feature of the two comparable complexes is, interestingly, all of the atz- ligands in 1 grow almost in one direction (along the c-axis direction) due to the N-H…O hydrogen bonding interactions.

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The asymmetric unit of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains one Zn(II) cation, one crystallographically independent anionic atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, one coordinated isonic<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> ligand and one isolated disorder Hisonic molecule, respectively. The coordination environment of the Zn atom is similar to that in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, where the four-coordinated Zn atom adopts a tetrahedral geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a). The isonic<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion and the atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion adopt monodentate <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridge coordination modes (b and d) to link two Zn atoms, respectively, and each Zn atom is surrounded by two atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands and two isonic<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands. The Zn–O<ce:inf loc="post">isonic</ce:inf> bond length is 1.948(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å). The Zn–N<ce:inf loc="post">atz</ce:inf> bond lengths are 1.975(3) and 1.992(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The mean Zn–N<ce:inf loc="post">atz</ce:inf> bond length (1.988(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å) is slightly shorter than that of Zn–N<ce:inf loc="post">isonic</ce:inf> (2.044(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å). All the Zn–N or Zn–O bond lengths are comparable to those previously reported Zn(II)–tetrazole complex , and the Zn(II)–isonic complex. The cis-angles at the central Zn atom fall in range of 107.0(1)–120.6(1)°, indicating that the tetrahedral geometries are slightly distorted.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of complex    2    

The asymmetric unit of compound 2 contains one Zn(II) cation, one crystallographically independent anionic atz-, one coordinated isonic- ligand and one isolated disorder Hisonic molecule, respectively. The coordination environment of the Zn atom is similar to that in complex 1, where the four-coordinated Zn atom adopts a tetrahedral geometry ( a). The isonic- anion and the atz- anion adopt monodentate μ 2-bridge coordination modes (b and d) to link two Zn atoms, respectively, and each Zn atom is surrounded by two atz- ligands and two isonic- ligands. The Zn-Oisonic bond length is 1.948(2)Å). The Zn-Natz bond lengths are 1.975(3) and 1.992(3)Å, respectively. The mean Zn-Natz bond length (1.988(3)Å) is slightly shorter than that of Zn-Nisonic (2.044(2)Å). All the Zn-N or Zn-O bond lengths are comparable to those previously reported Zn(II)-tetrazole complex , and the Zn(II)-isonic complex. The cis-angles at the central Zn atom fall in range of 107.0(1)-120.6(1)°, indicating that the tetrahedral geometries are slightly distorted.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn atoms are connected by the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-isonic<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>(N,O) ligand into a zigzag chain (b) along the [101] direction, then the zigzag chains are further linked to other four zigzag chains by four <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands in four directions to form a 3D porous framework (c). Interestingly, there exist weak zigzag H-bond chains formed by the amino groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (N1–H2…O2(♯4), 3.010<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, O1–H1…N1, 3.060<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å), along the [101] direction in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (Figure S2). These zigzag H-bond chains will be beneficial to the stabilization of the structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Taking Zn1 atoms as nodes, the connections representing isonic<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, the single 3D framework can be described as a 4-connected 3D topological network, with the short (Schläfli) vertex symbol  of 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> and the long topological (O’Keeffe) vertex symbol  of 6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, which is a typical diamondoid network (d). Inspection of Figure S3 reveals large channels with a hexagonal cross section. These intraframework voids are partly occupied by a second identical network. In other words, the two identical 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> nets are further interpenetrated in 2-fold mode (e). Notably, many interpenetration structures have been reported to date, it has been considered that the interpenetration structure is not consistent with the creation of porous structures because the cavities are usually occupied by the self-including structure . Remarkably, even if the interpenetration occurs in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, it still creates microporous channels with dimensional of about 3×5<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> (after exclusion of the van der Waals radii of the surface atoms), filled with disorder Hisonic molecules along the [101] direction (f, Figure S4).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In complex 2, the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn atoms are connected by the μ 2-isonic-(N,O) ligand into a zigzag chain (b) along the [101] direction, then the zigzag chains are further linked to other four zigzag chains by four μ 2-atz- ligands in four directions to form a 3D porous framework (c). Interestingly, there exist weak zigzag H-bond chains formed by the amino groups and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (N1-H2…O2(♯4), 3.010Å, O1-H1…N1, 3.060Å), along the [101] direction in 3 (Figure S2). These zigzag H-bond chains will be beneficial to the stabilization of the structure of 3. Taking Zn1 atoms as nodes, the connections representing isonic- and atz- anions, the single 3D framework can be described as a 4-connected 3D topological network, with the short (Schläfli) vertex symbol  of 66 and the long topological (O'Keeffe) vertex symbol  of 62⋅62⋅62⋅62⋅62⋅62, which is a typical diamondoid network (d). Inspection of Figure S3 reveals large channels with a hexagonal cross section. These intraframework voids are partly occupied by a second identical network. In other words, the two identical 66 nets are further interpenetrated in 2-fold mode (e). Notably, many interpenetration structures have been reported to date, it has been considered that the interpenetration structure is not consistent with the creation of porous structures because the cavities are usually occupied by the self-including structure . Remarkably, even if the interpenetration occurs in complex 2, it still creates microporous channels with dimensional of about 3×5Å2 (after exclusion of the van der Waals radii of the surface atoms), filled with disorder Hisonic molecules along the [101] direction (f, Figure S4).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">It should be emphasized that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are obtained from the similar condition except the second ligands Hnic and Hisonic are different but they are position-isomer ligands. However, little difference results into distinct features of the complexes. The reason for the two different structures is that the ligands nic and isonic have the difference in the coordination orientation of the two binding sites, py and carboxylate groups, straight for isonic, and bent for nic. The nic is bent and thus compensates for the tetrahedral Zn, and thus a 2D (4,4) sheet is formed. The isonic ligand, however, is linear, and so the tetrahedral geometry of the Zn then directs the formation of a 3D net with tetrahedral nodes. In other words, in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the linear chains were connected by atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand in two different directions (b), so complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a simple 2D square lattice structure. Whereas complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possessed a zigzag chain (b), the Zn atoms in the zigzag chain linked to other four identical chains by the atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand in four directions, and then construct a 3D framework with free Hisonic locating in the channels.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It should be emphasized that complex 1 and 2 are obtained from the similar condition except the second ligands Hnic and Hisonic are different but they are position-isomer ligands. However, little difference results into distinct features of the complexes. The reason for the two different structures is that the ligands nic and isonic have the difference in the coordination orientation of the two binding sites, py and carboxylate groups, straight for isonic, and bent for nic. The nic is bent and thus compensates for the tetrahedral Zn, and thus a 2D (4,4) sheet is formed. The isonic ligand, however, is linear, and so the tetrahedral geometry of the Zn then directs the formation of a 3D net with tetrahedral nodes. In other words, in complex 1, the linear chains were connected by atz- ligand in two different directions (b), so complex 1 is a simple 2D square lattice structure. Whereas complex 2 possessed a zigzag chain (b), the Zn atoms in the zigzag chain linked to other four identical chains by the atz- ligand in four directions, and then construct a 3D framework with free Hisonic locating in the channels.

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of complex    3    

Single crystal X-ray analysis shows that complex 3 is a non-interpenetrating 3D framework. It crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pbcm. The asymmetric unit of complex 3 contains half crystallorgraphically independent Cd(II) atom, half of a isonic ligand and a half atz ligand, respectively. The Cd center lies on a crystallorgraphic 2-fold axis and coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from two different atz- ligands (N3 and N3(i)) and one isonic ligand (N1(iv)), four oxygen atoms (O1, O1(ii) and O1(iii)) from the three different isoinic ligands to form a octahedron ( ). The equatorial plane of N3-O1(ii)-N(i)-O1(iii) is slightly distorted. The bond length of    Cd  -    N        atz    -        in the equatorial plane is 2.254(3)Å, which is close to those reported for the Cd-N complex , while the bond lengths of    Cd  -    N        isonic    -        (2.504(4)Å) on the axially ligated isonic ligand is little longer than the usual value. The    Cd  -    O        isonic    -        bond lengths (Cd-O1=2.635(3)Å, Cd-O1(ii)=2.419(3)Å) are slightly longer than normal, but are still in the range of those observed in the Cd/isonicotinate or nicotinate when the carboxylato group coordinate to the Cd atom by the μ 2,η 3-bridge fashion . In complex 3, the Cd atoms are linked into a double M-O-M (metal-oxygen-metal) chains by the μ 2, η 4-carboxylato groups along the b-axis direction. The neighboring double M-O-M chains are associated by the pyridyl ring spacer to provide a 2D layer, parallel to the (001) plane (b). The adjacent 2D layers are connected by the μ 2-atz bridging ligands into a three-dimensional pillared-layer structure (c). The 3D pillared-layer structure are further stabilized by the weak intralayer N-H…O hydrogen bonding interactions (N2-H2…O1(♯3), 2.954Å), via the amino groups donating H atoms to the carboxylate oxygen atoms.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Topologically, each isonic ligand is connected to four adjacent Cd centers through three Cd–O bonds and one Cd–N bond, and each Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion links with four isonic ligands and two atz ligands. Thus, the isonic ligand and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion can be defined as a 4- and 6-connected node and the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging atz ligand can be consider as linker between two 6-connected nodes. Based on this simplification, the structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be described as a (4,6)-connected “<ce:italic>fsc</ce:italic>” topological network , with the short (Schläfli) vertex symbol  of (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·8) and the long topological (O’Keeffe) vertex symbol  of (4·4·4·4·6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) (4·4·4·4·6<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·6<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>·<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup>·<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup>·<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup>) (d). It is a rarely observed topological net in coordination polymers. Although a few (4,6)-connected networks with two types of vertexes have been identified and categorized by O’Keeffe et. al., structures containing “<ce:italic>fsc</ce:italic>” topological network has been reported rarely. To the best of our knowledge, only one complex with <ce:italic>fsc</ce:italic>-type topology predicted by O’Keeffe in theory has been reported .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Topologically, each isonic ligand is connected to four adjacent Cd centers through three Cd-O bonds and one Cd-N bond, and each Cd2+ ion links with four isonic ligands and two atz ligands. Thus, the isonic ligand and Cd2+ ion can be defined as a 4- and 6-connected node and the μ 2-bridging atz ligand can be consider as linker between two 6-connected nodes. Based on this simplification, the structure of 3 can be described as a (4,6)-connected "fsc" topological network , with the short (Schläfli) vertex symbol  of (44⋅62)(44⋅610⋅8) and the long topological (O'Keeffe) vertex symbol  of (4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅62⋅62) (4⋅4⋅4⋅4⋅65⋅65⋅65⋅65⋅65⋅65⋅65⋅*⋅*⋅*) (d). It is a rarely observed topological net in coordination polymers. Although a few (4,6)-connected networks with two types of vertexes have been identified and categorized by O'Keeffe et. al., structures containing "fsc" topological network has been reported rarely. To the best of our knowledge, only one complex with fsc-type topology predicted by O'Keeffe in theory has been reported .

<ce:para view="all">Compared with complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, larger Cd atom radius and variable coordination number versus the Zn atom result into two distinct 3D networks. In complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, more coordination numbers of Cd atom need more coordination atom to coordinate with it, so the coordination number of Cd atom was completed by sharing the O atoms of the carboxyl and results into a Cd–COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>–Cd double chains, and then formed a “<ce:italic>fsc</ce:italic>” topological network through the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-atz bridging ligand. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn atoms are completed by the N and O atoms of the isonic or atz ligand and formed zigzag chains, and then the chains were connected into a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework by the bridging atz ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compared with complex 2, larger Cd atom radius and variable coordination number versus the Zn atom result into two distinct 3D networks. In complex 3, more coordination numbers of Cd atom need more coordination atom to coordinate with it, so the coordination number of Cd atom was completed by sharing the O atoms of the carboxyl and results into a Cd-COO--Cd double chains, and then formed a "fsc" topological network through the μ 2-atz bridging ligand. In complex 2, the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn atoms are completed by the N and O atoms of the isonic or atz ligand and formed zigzag chains, and then the chains were connected into a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D framework by the bridging atz ligand.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>IR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The IR spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (see Figure S5, Supporting information), show the characteristic bands of the carboxylic groups in the usual region at 1392–1449<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the symmetric vibrations and at 1619–1625<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the asymmetric vibrations. The absence of the peak around 1661<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which is observed in the starting Hnic or Hisoinc material, indicates that all carboxyl groups of organic moieties in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are deprotonated. The complexes show several strong band in the range of 3202–3417<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which can be assigned to the ν(NH) stretching frequency of the NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group . In the range of 994–1087<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> many deformation vibrations and combinations of the tetrazole ring can be found.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectroscopy

The IR spectra of complexes 1-3 (see Figure S5, Supporting information), show the characteristic bands of the carboxylic groups in the usual region at 1392-1449cm-1 for the symmetric vibrations and at 1619-1625cm-1 for the asymmetric vibrations. The absence of the peak around 1661cm-1, which is observed in the starting Hnic or Hisoinc material, indicates that all carboxyl groups of organic moieties in 2 are deprotonated. The complexes show several strong band in the range of 3202-3417cm-1, which can be assigned to the ν(NH) stretching frequency of the NH2 group . In the range of 994-1087cm-1 many deformation vibrations and combinations of the tetrazole ring can be found.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Thermal stability analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The thermal stability of the complexes in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were examined by the TG techniques in the temperature range of 40–900<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor> shows the TG curves for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C/min under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere. As shown in , there is no weight loss before 320<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C. A sharp weight loss for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> occurred about the temperature range of 320.0–550.0<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: obsd, 69.13%, calcd, 70.03%; for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>: obsd, 60.08%, calcd, 59.70%) corresponding to the release of the atz and nic (isonic for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) ligands. In the wide temperature range of 320–800<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>°C, weight loss of 76.02% was observed for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, which is attributed to the departure of Hisonic free molecules and the release of the atz and isonic ligands (calcd: 75.06). Finally, the probable residua are metal-oxide from the calculating value of the weight loss.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal stability analyses

The thermal stability of the complexes in N2 were examined by the TG techniques in the temperature range of 40-900°C.   shows the TG curves for complex 1-3 at a heating rate of 10°C/min under N2 atmosphere. As shown in , there is no weight loss before 320°C. A sharp weight loss for 1 and 3 occurred about the temperature range of 320.0-550.0°C (for 1: obsd, 69.13%, calcd, 70.03%; for 3: obsd, 60.08%, calcd, 59.70%) corresponding to the release of the atz and nic (isonic for 3) ligands. In the wide temperature range of 320-800°C, weight loss of 76.02% was observed for 2, which is attributed to the departure of Hisonic free molecules and the release of the atz and isonic ligands (calcd: 75.06). Finally, the probable residua are metal-oxide from the calculating value of the weight loss.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Fluorescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The solid-state fluorescent properties of the complexes were investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>, upon excitation of these solid samples at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=340<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm, the intense broad emission bands at 410<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 455<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 442<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, are observed. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm, there is no obvious emission observed for the free Hisonic ligand under the same experimental conditions, while free Hatz ligand presents a weak photoluminescence emission at 325<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm according to the reported literature. Therefore, the fluorescent emission of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> may be proposed to originate from the coordination of isonic<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> to the Zn and Cd atom (ligand-to-metal charge transition, LMCT). Further compared with complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the emission of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> becomes stronger, which is probably due to the differences of the metal ions. The density of electron cloud for oxygen atoms and the nitrogen atoms may be changed by the coordination of the metal ions . The free Hnic exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 379 and 512<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>=330<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm). Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may also be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT). Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are air-stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. These coordination polymers may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials because they are highly thermally stable.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent properties

The solid-state fluorescent properties of the complexes were investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in  , upon excitation of these solid samples at λ=340nm, the intense broad emission bands at 410nm for 1, 455nm for 2, 442nm for 3, are observed. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480nm, there is no obvious emission observed for the free Hisonic ligand under the same experimental conditions, while free Hatz ligand presents a weak photoluminescence emission at 325nm according to the reported literature. Therefore, the fluorescent emission of 2 and 3 may be proposed to originate from the coordination of isonic- to the Zn and Cd atom (ligand-to-metal charge transition, LMCT). Further compared with complex 2, the emission of complex 3 becomes stronger, which is probably due to the differences of the metal ions. The density of electron cloud for oxygen atoms and the nitrogen atoms may be changed by the coordination of the metal ions . The free Hnic exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 379 and 512nm (λ ex=330nm). Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may also be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT). Complexes 1-3 are air-stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. These coordination polymers may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials because they are highly thermally stable.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In summary, we have successfully applied mixed-ligand to construct three new coordination polymers with the second pyridylcarboxylate ligand and the <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate. Distinct spatial structural features in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were result from the position-isomer ligand. Simple “<ce:italic>sql</ce:italic>” topological 2D wave layers were connected into a 3D supramolecular structure via weak <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> stacking interaction for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Interpenetrated 3D framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with 1D channel was constructed by the <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> generated bridging atz ligand and the bridging isonic ligand, non-interpenetrated 3D framework of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with a rarely observed “<ce:italic>fsc</ce:italic>” topology. These results reveal that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is reliable to achieve unusual MOFs in tetrazole-based system. From the investigation of the fluorescent properties, complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> may be potential blue fluorescence material. The further investigations on such an interesting system are still in progress.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully applied mixed-ligand to construct three new coordination polymers with the second pyridylcarboxylate ligand and the in situ generated ligand of 5-amino-tetrazolate. Distinct spatial structural features in complex 1 and 2 were result from the position-isomer ligand. Simple "sql" topological 2D wave layers were connected into a 3D supramolecular structure via weak π…π stacking interaction for 1. Interpenetrated 3D framework of 2 with 1D channel was constructed by the in situ generated bridging atz ligand and the bridging isonic ligand, non-interpenetrated 3D framework of 3 with a rarely observed "fsc" topology. These results reveal that the mixed-ligand synthetic approach is reliable to achieve unusual MOFs in tetrazole-based system. From the investigation of the fluorescent properties, complexes 1-3 may be potential blue fluorescence material. The further investigations on such an interesting system are still in progress.

Synthesis of   [  Zn  (  atz  ) (  nic  )   ]   n   (  1  )   

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2975g, 1.0mmol), NaN3 (0.0325g, 0.5mmol), DCDA (DCDA=dicyandiamide, 0.042g, 0.5mmol), Hnic (0.122g, 1.0mmol) ethanol (2ml) and water (8ml) was stirred for 30min in air ( ), then sealed in a 23ml Teflon autoclave and heated at 130°C for 3 days. After the sample was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°C/h, colorless lamellar crystals were obtained in ca. 38% yield based on Zn. Anal. found: C, 31.03%; H, 2.21%; N, 30.91%. Calcd for Zn2C14H12N12O4 (MW=543.10): C, 30.96%; H, 2.23%; N, 30.95%.

Synthesis of   [  Zn  (  atz  ) (  isonic  )   ]   n   ⋅ n (  Hisonic  ) (  2  )   

The hydrothermal procedure for the preparation of complex 2 is similar to that for 1 except by replacement of Hnic with Hisonic. Colorless pillar crystals were obtained in ca. 46% yield based on Zn. Anal. found: C, 35.53%; H, 2.21%; N, 28.81%. Calcd for ZnC10H8N7O3 (MW=339.60): C, 35.36%; H, 2.37%; N, 28.87%.

Synthesis of   [  Cd  (  atz  ) (  isonic  )   ]   n   (  3  )   

Similarly, complex 3 was prepared in the same manner as that for 2 but with Cd(NO3)2⋅2H2O to replace Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O. Colorless pillar crystals were obtained in ca. 46% yield based on Cd. Anal. found: C, 26.41%; H, 1.88%; N, 26.31%. Calcd for CdC7H6N6O2 (MW=318.58): C, 26.39%; H, 1.90%; N, 26.38%.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of complex    3    

Single crystal X-ray analysis shows that complex 3 is a non-interpenetrating 3D framework. It crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pbcm. The asymmetric unit of complex 3 contains half crystallorgraphically independent Cd(II) atom, half of a isonic ligand and a half atz ligand, respectively. The Cd center lies on a crystallorgraphic 2-fold axis and coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from two different atz- ligands (N3 and N3(i)) and one isonic ligand (N1(iv)), four oxygen atoms (O1, O1(ii) and O1(iii)) from the three different isoinic ligands to form a octahedron ( ). The equatorial plane of N3-O1(ii)-N(i)-O1(iii) is slightly distorted. The bond length of    Cd  -    N        atz    -        in the equatorial plane is 2.254(3)Å, which is close to those reported for the Cd-N complex , while the bond lengths of    Cd  -    N        isonic    -        (2.504(4)Å) on the axially ligated isonic ligand is little longer than the usual value. The    Cd  -    O        isonic    -        bond lengths (Cd-O1=2.635(3)Å, Cd-O1(ii)=2.419(3)Å) are slightly longer than normal, but are still in the range of those observed in the Cd/isonicotinate or nicotinate when the carboxylato group coordinate to the Cd atom by the μ 2,η 3-bridge fashion . In complex 3, the Cd atoms are linked into a double M-O-M (metal-oxygen-metal) chains by the μ 2, η 4-carboxylato groups along the b-axis direction. The neighboring double M-O-M chains are associated by the pyridyl ring spacer to provide a 2D layer, parallel to the (001) plane (b). The adjacent 2D layers are connected by the μ 2-atz bridging ligands into a three-dimensional pillared-layer structure (c). The 3D pillared-layer structure are further stabilized by the weak intralayer N-H…O hydrogen bonding interactions (N2-H2…O1(♯3), 2.954Å), via the amino groups donating H atoms to the carboxylate oxygen atoms.

Thermal stability analyses

The thermal stability of the complexes in N2 were examined by the TG techniques in the temperature range of 40-900°C.   shows the TG curves for complex 1-3 at a heating rate of 10°C/min under N2 atmosphere. As shown in , there is no weight loss before 320°C. A sharp weight loss for 1 and 3 occurred about the temperature range of 320.0-550.0°C (for 1: obsd, 69.13%, calcd, 70.03%; for 3: obsd, 60.08%, calcd, 59.70%) corresponding to the release of the atz and nic (isonic for 3) ligands. In the wide temperature range of 320-800°C, weight loss of 76.02% was observed for 2, which is attributed to the departure of Hisonic free molecules and the release of the atz and isonic ligands (calcd: 75.06). Finally, the probable residua are metal-oxide from the calculating value of the weight loss.

Fluorescent properties

The solid-state fluorescent properties of the complexes were investigated at room temperature. As illustrated in  , upon excitation of these solid samples at λ=340nm, the intense broad emission bands at 410nm for 1, 455nm for 2, 442nm for 3, are observed. For excitation wavelengths between 280 and 480nm, there is no obvious emission observed for the free Hisonic ligand under the same experimental conditions, while free Hatz ligand presents a weak photoluminescence emission at 325nm according to the reported literature. Therefore, the fluorescent emission of 2 and 3 may be proposed to originate from the coordination of isonic- to the Zn and Cd atom (ligand-to-metal charge transition, LMCT). Further compared with complex 2, the emission of complex 3 becomes stronger, which is probably due to the differences of the metal ions. The density of electron cloud for oxygen atoms and the nitrogen atoms may be changed by the coordination of the metal ions . The free Hnic exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 379 and 512nm (λ ex=330nm). Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emissions of 1 may also be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transition (LMCT). Complexes 1-3 are air-stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. These coordination polymers may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials because they are highly thermally stable.

<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) View of the coordination environment of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 0.5−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> and (ii) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. (b) View of the Zn–Zn linear chain connected by the bridging nic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the wavy 2D layer structure constructed from Zn–Zn linear chains and atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands. (d) Topological view of the 2D 4-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> networks. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn2+ in complex 1 at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) 0.5-x, 0.5+y, z and (ii) x, 0.5-y, 0.5+z. (b) View of the Zn-Zn linear chain connected by the bridging nic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the wavy 2D layer structure constructed from Zn-Zn linear chains and atz- ligands. (d) Topological view of the 2D 4-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of 44⋅62 networks. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) View of the coordination environment of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> and (ii) −0.5+<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −0.5+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. (b) View of the Zn–Zn zigzag chain connected by the bridging isonic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the single 3D network constructed from the Zn–Zn zigzag chains and the atz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands. (d) Topological view showing the individual diamondoid network for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> along approximate [001] direction with the Schläfli symbol of 66 network. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls. (e) View of the 2-fold-interpenetrated 3D topological network for 2 constructed from two identical diamondoid net along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis. Zn nodes are represented by cyan and purple balls. (f) View of the 2-fold interpenetration 3D network for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> including free Hisonic in the cavities. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) View of the coordination environment of Zn2+ in complex 2 at 30%, Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (i) x, -y, 0.5+z and (ii) -0.5+x, 0.5-y, -0.5+z. (b) View of the Zn-Zn zigzag chain connected by the bridging isonic ligands (arrowhead for Zn atoms indicating the coordination direction). (c) View of the single 3D network constructed from the Zn-Zn zigzag chains and the atz- ligands. (d) Topological view showing the individual diamondoid network for complex 2 along approximate [001] direction with the Schläfli symbol of 66 network. Zn nodes are represented by cyan balls. (e) View of the 2-fold-interpenetrated 3D topological network for 2 constructed from two identical diamondoid net along c-axis. Zn nodes are represented by cyan and purple balls. (f) View of the 2-fold interpenetration 3D network for complex 2 including free Hisonic in the cavities. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

<ce:figure id="fig3">

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) View of the coordination environment of Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> at 50% probability level with labeling schedule. Hydrogen atoms are omitted. Symmetry codes: (i) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (ii) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (iii) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 0.5+<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (iv) 1+<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> and (vi) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 0.51−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. (b) Single 2D framework constructed from the double M–O–M chains and the pyridyl ring spacers. (c) View of the 3D framework in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> formed by the pillared atz ligand along the bc plane. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: blue=N; gray=C; red=O; cyan=Cd. (d) View of the 3D (4,6)-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>·8) network for complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. Cd and isonic nodes are represented by blue and cyan balls, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) View of the coordination environment of Cd2+ in complex 3 at 50% probability level with labeling schedule. Hydrogen atoms are omitted. Symmetry codes: (i) x, 0.5-y, 1-z; (ii) -x, -y, 1-z; (iii) -x, 0.5+y, z; (iv) 1+x, y, z and (vi) x, y, 0.51-z. (b) Single 2D framework constructed from the double M-O-M chains and the pyridyl ring spacers. (c) View of the 3D framework in 3 formed by the pillared atz ligand along the bc plane. The hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: blue=N; gray=C; red=O; cyan=Cd. (d) View of the 3D (4,6)-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of (44⋅62)(44⋅610⋅8) network for complex 3. Cd and isonic nodes are represented by blue and cyan balls, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

metadata.title:
Synthesis, crystal structures and properties of three new mixed-ligand d
               10 metal complexes constructed from pyridinecarboxylate and in situ generated amino-tetrazole ligand
